user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_rq_bauth_params_:
```c
const struct MHD_RqBAuth *
MHD_get_rq_bauth_params_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct _MHD_str_w_len h_auth_value;
  struct MHD_RqBAuth *bauth;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED <= connection->state);

  if (connection->rq.bauth_tried)
    return connection->rq.bauth;

  if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > connection->state)
    return NULL;

  if (! find_auth_rq_header_ (connection, MHD_AUTHTYPE_BASIC, &h_auth_value))
  {
    connection->rq.bauth_tried = true;
    connection->rq.bauth = NULL;
    return NULL;
  }

  bauth =
    (struct MHD_RqBAuth *)
    MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (connection, sizeof (struct MHD_RqBAuth));

  if (NULL == bauth)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Not enough memory in the connection's pool to allocate " \
                 "for Basic Authorization header parsing.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    return NULL;
  }

  memset (bauth, 0, sizeof(struct MHD_RqBAuth));
  if (parse_bauth_params (h_auth_value.str, h_auth_value.len, bauth))
    connection->rq.bauth = bauth;
  else
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("The Basic Authorization client's header has "
                 "incorrect format.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    connection->rq.bauth = NULL;
    /* Memory in the pool remains allocated until next request */
  }
  connection->rq.bauth_tried = true;
  return connection->rq.bauth;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No occurrences of modifying the function parameter itself were found. The only function parameter is the pointer 'connection'. The code reads and writes members of the object pointed to by 'connection' (for example: connection->rq.bauth_tried = true; connection->rq.bauth = NULL; connection->rq.bauth = bauth; uses connection->state; passes connection to helper functions). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is allowed by Rule 17.8; the rule prohibits modifying the pointer parameter variable itself (e.g., reassigning connection, incrementing/decrementing it, or storing its address elsewhere). There are no statements reassigning 'connection' (no "connection = ..."), no pointer arithmetic on 'connection', and no other parameters present. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
